sentences.sContent: Police had to be called in to control the crowds.
sentences.sCn: 只好调来警察控制人群。

sentences.sContent: He controlled the urge to laugh.
The disease robs you of muscle control.
sentences.sCn: 这种疾病会让你丧失肌肉控制力。

sentences.sContent: ...finds that the best way to ensure employees are “engaged” is to give them more control over where and how they do their work―which may mean liberating them from having to do everything in collaboration with others...
..."people think of aging as natural and something you can't control" he said...
...So here's a suggestion offered by two researchers at the Rand Corporation: Why not take a lesson from alcohol control policies and apply them to where food is sold and how it's displayed...
...many regulations that don't assume people make rational choices have been successfully applied to control alcohol...
...They found clock timers to be more efficient but less happy because they felt little control over their lives...
...The author found a former Montessori teacher exercising strict control over her kids' screen time...
...many regulations that don't assume people make rational choices have been successfully applied to control alcohol...
...So here's a suggestion offered by two researchers at the Rand Corporation: Why not take a lesson from alcohol control policies and apply them to where food is sold and how it's displayed...
...that doesn't control the cost of education; it just shifts it to taxpayers...
...The so-called mindful-eating strategies can fight distractions and help us control our appetite...

synos.tran: [自]控制；[管理]管理；抑制；操纵装置

phrases.pCn: 处于控制之下；情况正常
控制组（自变量的一种处理方法）；实验对照组

words.tran: 受控制的；受约束的；克制的
可控制的；可管理的；能操纵的
主计员或管理员之职位或任期
控制；约束（control的过去式）；指挥

trans.tranOther: to make someone or something do what you want, or make something happen in the way that you want
the ability or power to make someone or something do what you want or make something happen in the way you want
